title: Ceropegia fusca
text:
Ceropegia fusca is a <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the genus "<a href="Ceropegia">Ceropegia</a>" (<a href="Apocynaceae">Apocynaceae</a>). It is <a href="endemic%20%28ecology%29">endemic</a> to the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a>, where it grows on <a href="Tenerife">Tenerife</a> (especially the <a href="Macizo%20de%20Anaga">Macizo de Anaga</a> area), <a href="Gran%20Canaria">Gran Canaria</a>, and <a href="La%20Palma">La Palma</a> in the Tabaibal-Cardonal zone at up to about 600 m altitude.
Description.
The "Ceropegia fusca" plant forms erect woody stems reaching to 1.5 m tall. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a>, arranged in opposite pairs, each leaf narrow, 5 cm long. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are produced in clusters of two to five in the leaf axils; they are tubular, reddish brown, with five narrow lobes joined at the tip; flowering is in spring to summer. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a pair of large <a href="capsule%20%28fruit%29">capsules</a> up to 10 cm long.
Cultivation.
"Ceropegia fusca" is used as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a> in dry and <a href="xeriscape">drought tolerant</a> water conserving gardens. It requires hot conditions to grow well.
